elementText.text:
Pledge of slaves to secure a silver debt.
B1, fB2 (wife of B1) and B3 owe 1/3 shekels of silver to A. The payment is secured by the pledge of a female slave (fC1) and her son (C2).  fC1 should work for the creditor (našpartu alāku), while her son should work for his mother (našpartu alāku), probably meaning that he cannot be taken from her but should still assist her in her work. 8 shekels of the indebted silver is with one-fifth alloy (hummušu) and 12 shekels is with one-eighth alloy (bitqu).  Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe: Mušēzib-Marduk/Pir’u//Arad-Nergal.
 
A = Kurbanni-Marduk/Bēl-nāṣir//Rab-banê; B1 = Pir'u/Marduk-ušallim//Ahu’û; fB2 = fGagāya, wife of B1; B3 = Zēria/Lâbāši//Ahu’û; fC1 = fAhāt-abišu, slave; C2 =Barīk-il, slave, son of fC1

elementText.text:
As soon as the slave C (qallu) will have left from (or: turn up in) (elû Gt, Perf. i-te-la-a) A’s house, A will give a daily compensation payment (mandattu) amounting to 0;0.1 kor (c. 6 l) of barley to the slave's master (B). Otherwise, C will return and hand over to B (târu D – nadānu) a document (u’iltu) in which it is stated that he took A as a pledge (maškanu ṣabātu), or that he has purchased him for the corresponding exact price (šīm hariṣ). Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Arad-Illat/Marduk-šarrāni//Nannāya.
 
A = Nabû-ēṭir/Nummuru/Nabāya; B = Zēria/Nabû-ibni//Nabāya; C = Uqūpu, slave of B

elementText.text:
Court protocol.
A, B’s slave, says thus to the judges of Nabonidus: “B loaded a shipment of 480 kor (c. 86400 l) of epirūtu-dates from the hinterland onto C‘s boat (C being a boatman, mallāhu), who was responsible for the shipping. When the boat arrived to Babylon, C gave me A’s message (šipirtu) that recorded the amount of 480 kor (c. 86400 l), but after a verification I have found that 47;1 kor (c. 8496 l) of dates were missing. I raised a claim against C concerning the shortfall (miṭītu), but he denied having taken the dates and has not refunded the loss. Therefore I have brought him before you: establish your decision!”. The judges heard this deposition, read the pertinent written documents and interrogated C: they established that C must give 40 kor (c. 7200 l) of dates to A, corresponding to the shortfall of dates from the original load. Names of 5 judges and the scribe.
 
A = Nergal-rēṣūa; B = Iddin-Marduk; C = Amurru-natan/Ammāya

elementText.text:
Pledge of a house. Very fragmentary.
B’s house is pledged (maškanu) to A. The debtor will pay each day 3 qa (c. 18 l) of bread. Rest broken off, possibly referring a.o. to Bēl-abu-uṣur, a oblate (širku). Names of witnesses broken off, name of the scribe: …/Iddin-Nabû//Egibi.
 
A = Nergal-ušēzib/Kabtia//Suhāya; B = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi

elementText.text:
Negative assertory oath. Very Fragmentary.
Apart from the first 3 lines, the middle part of the tablet is broken. A swears (tamû) before Bēl, Nabû and king Darius that except (alla) for 1 promissory note issued (verb is lost in a lacuna) on the name of D…The following line is fragmentary and mentions a claim (rašûtu) of/which E. Approximately 5 lines are missing. A fragmentary passage before the list of witnesses mentions that A will bring along (abāku) C (his co-debtor?) to Babylon and will settle (qatû) his lawsuit (dibbu) with (itti) B. See also BM 30733 (Dar 187). Fragmentary names of 3 witnesses. The scribe is Munahhiš-Marduk/Bānia//Egibi.
 
A = Šaddinnu/Nabû-šumu-ukīn//Mandidi; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; C = Šiška/Marduk-erība/Sinkarabi§emme; D = Kalbāya (without affiliation); E =Aplāya/[…]

elementText.text:
Interim settlement of accounts within the framework of a business partnership (harranu).
Concerns the assets worth 1 mina and 10 shekels that belong to the business partnership that A and B established: 40 empty barrels valued at 23 1/3 shekels of silver (ana kaspi manû), from among which 10 are for full-strength beer (ṭābu), including 2 fermenting vats (namzītu) and 2 beer vat stands (namharu),  bronze and iron tools a.o. a bronze cooking vessel (mušahhinu) ša talammu (unc.) of 2 shekels of silver, pieces of furniture, scrap silver (qallalu), and credit balances for 38 shekels of silver that should be paid partly in dates (by C) and partly in silver (by D, who is identified as the one who is running the business, našpartu alāku).  After listing the assets the document states that they are at B's disposal (ina pāni). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Erība-Marduk/Šulāya//Pappāya.
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; B = Rēmūt/Kurbanni-Marduk//Eppeš-ilī; C = Nergal-iddin; D = Bēl-iddin/Nergal-uballiṭ

elementText.text:
Sale of a slave.
fA (D’s wife) had pledged her slave C to E (bīt maškānu ša E), and then (re-)claimed (paqāru) from him the pledged slave that she sold to him for a hariṣ-price amounting to 50 shekels of silver. Now she sells the slave of her own free will to B for the same hariṣ-price, 50 shekels of silver. fA guarantees against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that C is a royal slave (arad šarrūtu) or a free person (mār banê). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
fA = fĒṭirtu/Ahhē-iddin, wife of D; B = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; C = Nabûma-attū'a; D = Itti-Nabû-balāṭu/Zēria; E = Ina-tēšê-ēṭir (also written Tēšê-ēṭir)

elementText.text:
Annulment of slave purchase.
fA (D‘s wife) sold the slave C together with his wife and six children to B, for 24 minas of medium quality silver, of which 1/8 is alloy. A sealed document about these slaves (ameluttu) had been issued at her request (ana ṣibûti) giving B title (šumu) to the slaves. The buyer, however, did not pay the sum of silver that had been agreed upon in the sale document (šá ina šāṭari šaṭru), and had therefore to return it (târu D – nadānu) to fA. Should a copy turn up (in the future) it belongs to fA. Names of 8 witnesses and the scribe.
 
fA = fAmat-Bāba/Kalbāya//Nabāya, wife of D; B = Marduk-Bēlšunu/Arad-Marduk//Šangû-Ea; C = Madān-bēlu-uṣur; D = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi

elementText.text:
Pledge of a house with antichresis. Security for a silver debt.
A owes to fB 1 mina of white medium quality silver, of which 1/8 is alloy. fB takes his house, located near C’s house, as a pledge. She will pay no rent and there will be no interest on silver, until fB will be paid. The house will be at her disposal for two years. Names of 5 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; fB = fNadât-Ninlil/Iddināya//Ea-kabti-ilī; C = Hašdāya/Nin-EZENxGU4-šarru-uṣur

elementText.text:
Undated short notice.
A short note about 25 3/4 mina of silver that are at the disposal (ina pāni) of A (and hence due from him). It is an outstanding obligation (rēhu). No date, place, witnesses or a scribe are mentioned. 
 
A=Iddin-Marduk(/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn)

elementText.text:
Fragmentary
The upper and bottom part of the tablet are broken off. The conserved part of the tablet mentions the existence of promissory notes (u'iltu) of 82;1.0.0. kor of dates including (adi) the tithe of Nergal en Bēlet-ilē. The dates are the estimated income from imposts (imittu) from C’s fields. A, C’s agent (Bēl-bīti), should deliver them on or from (ina) B’s harbu land because B established in Babylon the promissory notes in both their names (e’ēlu).
This is in addition to (elat) … The rest of the upverse is broken off. Legible on the other side of the tablet is the verb eṭēru and the name of B. A will deliver from (ultu) …(broken off) in accordance with B’s promissory notes to B. This is in addition to (elat) 7;2.3.0 kor of dates due by A.
Names of 2 witnesses, the name of the 3rd witness and the scribe are broken off.
 
A = Šumu-ukīn/Ša-Nabû-šū; B = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; C = Nergal-nāṣir/Nādin

elementText.text:
Undertaking to deliver.
In this document, someone whose name is not written explicitly (possibly A) commits to delivering sheep and a garment to C. The latter had received (mahāru) 6 kor of dates (c. 1080 l) from A who took as a security (ubbuṭu) for the (return of the) dates 12 sheep and 1 KUR.RA-garment– that had been entrusted (paqdu) to C -, and 2 more (elat) sheep, that belong to B. Thus, in total, A took 14 sheep and 1 KUR-RA-garment from C. Now, he (A?) will pay C in full (eṭēru D - nadānu) the sheep and the garment by the end of  Tašrīt (VII). Names of 2 witnesses (including B) and the scribe: Nabû-ēṭir-napšāti/Kiribtu//Bēl-aplu-uṣur.
 
A = Marduk-balāssu-iqbi/Erība-Marduk//Bēliau; B = Bēl-apla-iddin/Kabtia//Bābūtu; C = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn

elementText.text:
Purchase of land. Receipt of purchase price
A buys 0;1.5.5.8 sq. kor (c. 5325 m2) of land from fB for 1 minas and 55 1/2 shekels of silver. It is a plot of land located in the open country (ṣēru), an orchard (kirû) planted with date palms (gišimmarē zaqpu) bearing fruit (iṣṣi bilti) and ... (lacuna), within (birīt) the upper palmgrove (gišimmaru elēnu) in Hursagkalamma, in the district (pīhatu) of Kiš. The field is described according to the neighbouring properties (among others, the house of the šatammu), then it is acknowledged that fB has received (mahāru Stat.) 1 mina and 55 ½ shekels of silver as the total purchase price (šīmu gamru) for this land, plus 2 ½ shekels as additional payment (atru). In total, fB receives 2 minas and 1 shekels of clipped silver (šibirtu) from A. The parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other, not even between members of their families – otherwise, any future claimant will have to repay twelvefold the silver he received. Names of 4+ witnesses (introduced by the formula ina kanakka ṭuppi šuati). A broken passage at the end of the witness list and before the scribe’s name, refers to fB, “seller” (nādinatu) of the field; then it is said that her daughter fC, also labelled“seller” (nādinatu) of the field, whose equalising payment (takpurtu) corresponds to 1 shekel of silver, was present(?) (ina ušuzzi or ina ašabi, reconstructed). This is followed by the name of the scribe: Bēl-ibni/Bēlšunu//Rē'i-sīsê. Finally, the text states that the fingernails (ṣupru) of the seller are impressed on the tablet instead of her seal impression (kunukku).
 
A = Kalbāya/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; fB = fInbāya/Nabû?/Seppe; fC = fRē’indu

elementText.text:
House rental.
A rents a house near C’s house, including the annexes (ṭipu) that he owns together with D, for a one-year period (ana ṭuppi ana ṭuppi) to B. The rent is fixed at 1/2 mina and 2 shekels of stamped silver (ginnu) used for purchases and sales (nadanu u maharu). It is agreed that half of the silver should be paid at the beginning of the year, and the remainder in the middle. The renter should caulk (šanû) the roof and repair the wall foundations (asurrû). He should also pay for the additional payment (nūptu) in Nisan (I), Dûzu (IV) and Kislim (IX). The house is at the renter’s disposal from the 15th of Simān (III) onwards. D will set doors into the doorways (daltu zaqāpu). Should the landlord break the contract, he will have to pay an unknown amount of silver (the tablet is broken in this point). The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. D will roof (ṣullulu) the rest of the annexes (ṭipāni); he will give them to B. Names of 6 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Marduk-ēṭir/Nabû-šumu-iškun//Mušallim; C = Bēl-uballiṭ/Bēl-ēṭir-napšāti//Atkuppu; D = Nergal-ušēzib

elementText.text:
House Rental.
A rents his house located near the Marbiti-Temple to B, at a price of 1 mina and 10 shekels of silver per year plus a kīnayātu-gift amounting to 5 shekels of silver. It is agreed that half of the silver should be paid at the beginning of the year, and the remainder in the middle. The renter should caulk (šanû) the roof and repair the wall foundations (asurrû); he should also deliver 2 baskets of tābīlu-herbs each year. A has received (eṭēru) the rent for his house until the end of Abu (V) of Cambyses’ 7th regnal year from B. The house is at the renter’s disposal from Ulūl (VI) of Cambyses’s 6th regnal year onwards. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; B = Padāya/Nabû-mušētiq-uddê//Pahāru

elementText.text:
Purchase of land.
The top  of the tablet, which recorded the size and type of the purchased land with the topographical references, is lost: the only information one gets is that one side of the purchased plot of land is adjacent to the property of A, the buyer. The total purchase price of the field is also unknown, but the established ratio is 1 shekel of silver for each 0;0.0.1? Kor (75 m2?) of land, to which the buyer adds x+1/4 shekels of silver as additional payment (kî atru). B acknowledges that he has received (mahāru) the total amount of silver which was due to him, in pieces (šibirtu), and he is satisfied (apālu G Stat). The parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other, not even between members of their families – otherwise, any future claimant (pāqirānu) will have to repay twelvefold the silver he received. The names of the witnesses and of the scribe are lost.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Mušēzib-Bēl/Nabû-šumu-ukīn//Sîn-šadûnu

elementText.text:
Purchase of land.
A purchases two plots of land from three sisters, fB1, fB2 and fB3. Some details on this land are lost because of the fragmentary condition of the tablet, but from what is extant one infers that each partial area (mišihtu) was described according to its adjacent properties. The long side in the North of the first one was adjacent to (the property of) C1 and fC2, its side in the South to (the property of) fD, and its front in the East to (the property of) E. Any information on the second partial area (mišihtu) is lost. The rest of the tablet is also in a fragmentary state, but no doubt it must have recorded that A declares the equivalent for this land together with the sellers fB1, fB2 and fB3 (A itti B mahīra nabû išām) and that he gave (nadānu) the sister an unknown amount of silver, which included both the purchase price and the additional payment. fB1, fB2 and fB3 acknowledge that they received the silver and they are satisfied (aplā): finally, the usual warranty clause against future claims or suits between the two parties or members of their families follows. Names of 7 witnesses, all of them judges (dayyānu), and 3 scribes.
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; fB1 = fNadāya/Šamaš-udammiq//Maštuk; fB2 = fIna-Esagila-rāmat/Šamaš-udammiq//Maštuk; fB3 = fBēlilitu/Šamaš-udammiq//Maštuk; C1 = Nergal-ušallim/...//...; fC2 = f…/Nabû-zēru-ibni//Rē'i-sīsê; fD = fEtellitu/...//...; E = Bēl-Iqīša/Marduk-zēru-ibni//Qaqqadānītu

elementText.text:
Promissory note for silver.
B owes 2 minas of silver to A (ša A ina muhhi B), to be delivered in Kislīm (IX). This is what remains (rīhtu) to be paid for the purchase of a plot of land (eqlu) at the outlet (bābu) of the ancient Kutha canal, after it turned out that the field (zēru) was larger than what was calculated at the time of the sale. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe. The receipt for this silver is recorded in BM30532.
 
A = Šamaš-aplu-uṣur/Šamaš-ina-tēšê-ēṭir//Šangû-Šamaš; B = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi.

elementText.text:
Receipt for barley
A receives (mahāru) barley from B. This is the yield (ebūru) of the field from the 12th and the 13th year of Darius. Each of the partners has taken a copy of the present document. It is further pointed out that A received from B the entire purchase price (mimma ina šīmī). But it is not immediately clear whether or how this relates to the previous mentioned receipt of barley. At the end of line 11, there are signs in alphabetic script. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: A.
 
A = Širku/Iddināya//Egibi (aka Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi); B = Nabû-naṣir/Nādinu//Bābūtu

elementText.text:
Fragment of a tablet recording the purchase of land.
The purchased arable land is located along a ditch (harru) in front of the Uraš Gate in the district (pīḫatu) of Babylon. Land belonging to B is also mentioned, but in a fragmentary and unclear context. A declares the equivalent for this land together with the seller (whose name is lost) to be x+40 shekels of silver. Any other information is lost since the tablet breaks at this point.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Bēl-ahhē-iqīša/Nabû-šumu-iddin//Nādin-še'im

elementText.text:
Establishment of a business partnership.
A1 and A2, slaves of B established a business partnership and each of them invested 5 minas of silver into it. The partners agree that they will share equally in the profit of the 10 minas of silver. Names of 5 witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-bān-zēri/Nabā-tattannu-uṣur.
 
A1 = Bēl-kāṣir/Marduk-ušallim//Ašlāku, slave of B; A2 = Nabû-ajjalu, slave of B; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi

elementText.text:
Receipt for silver. Silver for manufacturing a necklace.
A manufactured (lit. "gave") a necklace (kišādu) with an ešru-mounting(?) (partly uncl.) for B in return for (a salary of) 10 shekels (ana 10 š kaspi). Out of this sum he acknowledges to have received 5 shekels of silver.  Cf. BM30522 (= Nbn 216); similar to Mnb1828 (= TCL 12, 101) and BM30875 (= Nbn 501).  Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-šumu-ukīn/Bēl-ušallim// Bābūtu (= craftsman/recipient).
 
A= Nabû-šumu-ukīn/Bēl-ušallim//Bābūtu ; B = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi

elementText.text:
Receipt of rental price.
B, the slave of the crown prince D, has purchased a plot of land located near (the land belonging to) C and the crown prince’s house, from A1 (who owns it as his inheritance share (pūt zitti) together with his wife fA2). The established purchase price amounts to 2/3 minas and 6 shekels of silver, and is apparently paid in instalments as the text refers, in this context, to a promissory note for 1/3 mina and 5 shekels of silver. A1 acknowledges that he has received the silver for his house from B,. The field will be inspected, and a receipt which attest to the full payment (ṭuppu apiltu) will be sealed. The paid silver will be reimbursed according to the market value. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.

A1 = Marduk-erība/Rēmūt//Miṣirāya; fA2 = fBāba-ēṭirat, wife of A1; B = Bēl-rēṣūa, servant of D; C = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; D = Bēl-šarru-uṣur, the crown prince

elementText.text:
Injunction.
By Abu (V), 2nd, of Darius’ 17th year A will pay (nadānu) 1 1/2 mina of medium-quality silver (nuhhutu), of which one-eighth is alloy (bitqu), which he owes to B. Should he fail to pay within this date, 2 gazelles (ṣabītu), […], and 1 gazelle, in total 4?! gazelles belonging to him will be made available to B (pāni dagālu N) on Abu (V), 15th, instead (kūm) of those 1 1/2 mina of silver. A pronounces an oath by the gods and the king. Rest broken off. Names of 8 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nabû-bullissu/Nabû-šumu-ukīn//La-kubburu; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi

elementText.text:
Receipt of silver. Partial payment. Purchase price of land.
A receives 10 minas of silver from B: this is part of the purchase price for arable land (zēru) located on the road to Kiš which C purchased (mahāru) 6 months earlier on B's behalf (see BM32849, and its duplicate BM30338, as well as BM31872). Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Kabtia/Tabnēa//Egibi; B = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; C = Nabû-šumu-uṣur/Nabû-kuzub-ilī//Rab-banê

elementText.text:
List of šibšu-tax
The text lists the incomes from the šibšu-tax “from the mountain” (ina šadî) of in sum 515 bundles (pītu) of onions (šūmi) for the different parties (A1, A2, A3, A4, A5, A6,) for which B, the Ašpagā of Šahrīnu, is responsible. 
200 bundles, the šibšu-tax of A1’s field “from the mountain” (ina šadî).
150 bundles, the šibšu-tax of A2’s field “from the mountain” (ina šadî).
50 bundles, the šibšu-tax of A3’s field “from the mountain” (ina šadî).
57 bundles, the šibšu-tax of the slaves A4  and A5’s field “from the mountain” (ina šadî).
58 bundles, the šibšu-tax of A6’s field “from the mountain” (ina šadî).
The tithe of Nergal is not paid (eṭēru). The names of the witnesses, the scribe, place and date are not mentioned.
 
A1 = Nabû-būniya; A2 = Nabû-ēṭir/Erebšu; A3 = Šellibi; A4 = Nabû-zēru-iddin, slave of … (name broken); A5 = Bēl-taklāk, slave of …. (name broken); A6 = Kalbāya/Pāširi; B = Bīt-ašarra-šarra-uṣur

elementText.text:
Addendum to a slave sale.
Concerns two persons (fC1 and C2, her son) whom A, slave of D bought (ana kaspi abāku, lit. took away for silver). The present document points out that also B witnessed the transfer (ina mukinnutu ašābu), thus implying his consent to it. Names of 3 witnesses, no name of scribe.
 
A = Nabû-uterri, slave of D; B = Rēmūt/Nabû-rēhti-uṣur; fC1= fBābānu-ṣullî-liṣṣur(?) [the reading is uncertain], mother of C2; C2 = Lūṣi-ana-nūri/Nabû-uterri (A); D = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi

elementText.text:
Promissory note for silver with antichretic pledge of a house.
B owes 50 shekels of medium quality silver, of which one-eighth is alloy to A. The payment is secured by the pledge of the debtor’s house located next to the houses of D and E. The creditor enjoys the usufruct of the house in lieu of receiving interest (antichresis). Accordingly, he does not pay rent for the house, and B does not pay interest on his debt until the A has been fully repaid his 50 shekels of silver. C can continue living in the house for another three years. B will be charged (manû) for whatever refurbishing work (dullu) that C does in it with bricks (libnāte), reeds (qanâte), beams (gušūri) or doors (daltu). Names of 6 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Itti-Nabu-balāṭu/Šumu-ukīn//Šigûa; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; C = Marduk-ēṭir (without affiliation); D = Bēl-uballiṭ; E = Nabû-ahu-…

elementText.text:
Exculpatory kunnu-summons about small livestock.
Concerns the 100 animals of small livestock (ṣēnu) of B1, slave of D. A said about D, the slave-owner, the following: B2, one of his slaves, took away (našû, wr. i-ta-aš!-šú!) these animals from me (lit. from my hand, ina qātiya). Should A establish the case against B2 (kânu D), he is clear (zakû). However, if he fails to do so, he should return the 100 animals to the slave-owner as well as the income from wool (gizzatu) and new-borns (tēlītu, wr. te!-lit-tú). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Adnadib/DINGIR ia-ha-ta; B1 = Kī-li-..., slave of D; B2 = Nabû-ṣābit-ritti, slave of D; D = Nergal-šarru-uṣur/Bēl-šumu-iškun; E = Adnalu.

elementText.text:
Promissory note for barley, within the framework of a business partnership (harrānu).
B owes 7.2.3.0 (kor) of barley to A, to be delivered in the full amount (gamru) in Ayyār (II) at the Borsippa canal in the village of Ahaiddin/Ardija. The (indebted) silver is what C invested in the business partnership. In addition, there are earlier promissory notes for silver and barley which are still pending. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Bēl-iddin/Bēl-upahhir//Dābibi.
                                                          
A  =Madān-šumu-iddin/Zēria//Nabāya; B = Gimillu/Luttua; C = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya.

elementText.text:
About the sale of a slave: settlement of a dispute between the sellers about their shares in the purchase price.
A purchased three slaves from B1 and his uncle B2, for 3 1/2 minas of silver. Out of this amount, B1 should have taken 2 minas and 10 shekels, and B2 the remaining 1 1/3 mina. Later, B2 brought a suit against B1 with regard to his share of the purchase price, but apparently he was not successful. In this tablet, in fact, one finds confirmation that B1 has taken possession of the 2 minas and 10 shekels of silver, his share in the purchase price. It is also stated that the two sellers B1 and B2 are the uškûtu-guarantors for the slaves, as established in the sale contract. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B1 = Nabû-iqīša/Šellibi//Atkuppu; B2 = Bēl- kēšir/Šulāya//Egibi, uncle of B1

elementText.text:
Establishment of a business partnership.
A1 and A2 invest 24;2.0.0 kor barley, worth 56 shekels of silver, in a business partnership with B, whom they regard accountable for this sum (ana muhhi manû) and to whom they granted a half share in it (ahu zitti šakānu). C is identified as the person who actually owes the barley to the partners. It is agreed that they will together collect it from him (lapāni esēru). A1 and A2 will be fully paid for their investment of 56 shekels (šalāmu G) from the common business capital (karû) and testify (pūt mukinnūti našû) that C still owes the 24;2.0.0 kor of barley, due from him for the month Kislīm (IX) from the previous year. A short remark at the end of the document qualifies the capital sum of silver as having 1/6 alloy. Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Kāṣir/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; A2 = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; B = Bēl-ile’’i/Šūzubu//Bēl-bani; C = Ubār-Nabû/Šum-Nabû

elementText.text:
Receipt
A1, acting as proxy for (ina našparti) his father A2, receives (mahāru) 5 shekels of silver from B for C᾽s urāšu-obligation. This is in addition to previous receipts (giṭṭu). Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe. 
 
A1 = Šamaš-iddin/Bāni-zēri//Sîn-šadûnu; A2 = Bāni-zēri; B = Marduk-rēmanni/Iddin-Marduk/Nūr-Sîn; C = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn

elementText.text:
Fixation of interest and pledge of a slave as securities for silver debts
B owes 10 ½ shekels of silver to A, on which he should pay a yearly interest of 20% on a monthly. In addition, there is earlier promissory note for 1 mina and 34 shekels of silver between the same parties on which B is paying interest since Nisan (I) of Nabonidus’ 11th year. The payment of the both debts is secured by the pledge of the debtor’s slave (C).
 
A = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; B = Mušēzib-Bēl/Zēria//Nabāya; C = Nabû-ušēzib, slave of B

elementText.text:
Receipt(?) for silver. Very fragmentary.
The tablet records an amount of silver which is lost in a lacuna at the beginning of the first line: this is what remains (rēhtu) (to be paid) from the purchase price (šīmu) for a plot of land. A has received (the verb is lost in a lacuna) from B. Rest broken off. Wunsch 2000, 188 suggests to consider B a proxy for Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi, and include this tablet in the Egibi archive. Names of witnesses broken off, only part of the affiliation of the scribe is readable: […]//Bā’iru.
 
A = Šamaš-aplu-uṣur / §ama§inate§ie#er/ §angu§ama§; B= .../...-mušētiq-uddê//Mudammiq-Adad (Probably: Gūzānu/Nabû-mušētiq-uddê//Mudammiq-Adad, cf. BM30868 and BM33912).

elementText.text:
Summon. Undertaking to bring along a witness before the (business) accounts can be settled.
As soon as A will have brought along (abāku) his witness who will testify (kunnu) against B, saying that A gave to B and C commodities (mēreštu) (to the value of) 2 1/2 minas of silver, then B will do (epēšu) the accounts with A and [...]. Whatever share (mimma pūt zitti) that he has (now) at his disposal is what remains (rīhu), each of them is B’s (?) (1-en-a B) (unc.). If the witness will not testify, then either he or the other one(?) (ištēnu šanû) (i.e. A or the witness) will return to B (tarû D – nadānu) whatever A took away (našû) from him. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi
 
A = Nabû-nā’id/Nabû-gāmil; B = Aia-ahhāya/Šaniāma; C = Baruhi-ilu

elementText.text:
Receipt for the partial payment of a silver debt.
Concerning the promissory note (u’iltu) for the total amount of 10 mina of silver, 71 kor of dates and 13 kor of barley belonging to A that are due from B.
Of this total debt A receives (mahāru) from B 71 kor of dates, 13 kor of dates. The parties have each taken a copy of this document.
Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Bēl-uballiṭ//Ir’anni] (= A).
See also the receipts: BM30255 (Dar. 545), BMUnknown(Dar536) and the promissory notes: BM30746 (Dar. 507); BM35338 (Dar. 462), BM31578 (Dar. 515).
 
A= Bēl-uballiṭ/Bēl-ēṭir//Ir’anni; B=Širku/Itti-Marduk-Balāṭu//Egibi

elementText.text:
Promissory note for silver. Fragmentary
B owes A 6 2/3 minas and 1 shekel of medium quality (nuhhutu) silver, of which 1/8 is alloy. From which (ina libbi) he will deliver (nadānu) (amount broken off) on the 4th day of Ṭebēt (X). The tablet is written on the 4th day of Ṭebēt (X). Cf. BM30309: a receipt for 4 mina of silver written on the 20th day of Ṭebēt (X).
The list of witnesses is fragmentary. The scribe is Bēl-ittannu/Nabû-uṣuršu//Rab-banê
 
A = Nabû-bān-ahi/Marduk-nāṣir//Adad-šammê; B = Šišku/Iddināya//Egibi

elementText.text:
Adoption agreement.
A of his own free will (ina hūd libbišu) gives in adoption (ana maruti nadanu) his son C to B, who is the brother of the child’s mother. B has been raising C since childhood and he has trained him in the art of reading and writing (liginnu šugbû). Now, as a result C is the son of B. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Arad-Marduk/Kabtia//Šangû-Ea.
 
A = Šuma-ukīn/Mušallim; B = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; C = Kalbāya

elementText.text:
Sale of a female slave and her baby.
A1 and her sister fA2, of their own free will, sell their female slave fC and her unweaned baby (ša muhhi tulû) to B1 and B2 for a hariṣ price amounting to 19 shekels of silver. The sellers guarantee against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that the slaves are royal slaves (arad šarrūtu) or free persons (mār banê). Damqāya, the sellers' mother is present (ina ašābi) at the conclusion of the sale. Names of 3 witnesses, and the scribe: Nūrēa/Ina-Esagil-zēri//…-Sîn.
 
A1 = Šamaš-uballiṭ/Zākir//Amēl-Isin, brother of fA2; fA2 = fUbārtu/Zākir//Amēl-Isin, sister of A1; B1 = Kāṣir; B2 = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; fC = fNana-kēširat

elementText.text:
Litigation.
The top part of the tablet is broken off; after this lacuna, the text records that someone (whose name is lost ) has shown (kalāmu D) something to A, who said: “I am not B’s son. C, my father’s brother, has adopted (leqû) me. Examine (bu‘û) B’s assets (nikkassu) and may (your claim) be fully paid (šalāmu)“. D1, D2 and D3 listened to him together, and […] the settlements (ālu) which belonged to B and his brother E [...] (text broken off, only A’s and B’s names are readable in a fragmentary passage). [...] A releases (muššuru) […] to D1 and D2. They will […] all the assets (nikkassu) belonging to B and E, and from them they will receive full payment (šalāmu) for what remains (rēhtu) of their credit (rašûtu) due by B. The tablet has been written in the presence of (ina ašābi) A’s mother. Names of 5 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Bēl-ahhē-iddin; B = Mušēzib-Marduk; C = Rēmūtu-Gula, uncle of A; D1 = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; D2 = Bēlšunu; D3 = broken off; E = Nabû-ēṭir-napšāti, brother of B

elementText.text:
Pledge of a house to secure a debt for house rent. Very fragmentary.
This tablet concerns the rent of a house from a month (whose name is broken) of Cambyses‘ 5th regnal year to the end of Ayyār (II) of […] (year broken). fA take fB’s house as a pledge (maškanu). C, D’s slave (qallu), has received (leqû) something lost in a line which cannot be read from E. The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
fA = fEsagila-…; fB = fNadāya; C = Nabû-ayyālu, slave of D; D = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; E = Gūzānu/Mušallim-Marduk//Ašgandu

elementText.text:
Memorandum concerning the transport and sale of dates.
The tablet relates to 447;2 kor (80500 litre) of dates which A, slave of B transported by boat and subsequently sold. The first boat (eleppu mahrītu) under A’s responsibility (ina pāni) transported 208;3.2.0 kor of dates of which 31;2.0.0 kor were sold without receipts (ša la giṭṭāni). The second boat, also under A’s responsibility transported of 208;3.4.0 kor of dates. B received (mahāru) the silver of the sale (from A). No date, witnesses or a scribe are mentioned. 
 
A = Nergal-rēṣūa B = Iddin-Marduk

elementText.text:
Settlement of accounts related to a dowry.
The two brothers B1 and B2  haven’t settled yet their accounts (epeš nikkassi qatû). It concerns silver which B1 received (ina pāni, lit. is at his disposal) in lieu of (kum) part of his wife’s dowry (fC) from his father-in-law D. It had apparently been invested in a business venture which was run by the two brothers (ina muhhi, lit. due from them). The explicit term for business venture, harranu, is not used. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Šāpik-zēri/Zēru-ukīn//Nabû-ēṭir
 
D=Zēria(//Nabāya); B1=Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; fC=fIna-Esagila-rāmat, daughter of D (and wife of B1); B2=Kāṣir (probably B1’s brother)

elementText.text:
Promissory note
B owes A1 10 mina of silver to be paid on the 15th of Nisan (I). The silver is the purchase price of 115 bundles (pītu) of onions “from the mountain” (ina šadî), A1’s share (pūt zitti) in a business with (itti) A2. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Bēl-iddin/Nabû-zēru-ušabši; A2 = Nabû-ēdu-uṣur/Rahianni; B: Nidinti-Bēl/Nabû-kuṣranni

elementText.text:
Court protocol.
A1 and A2, B’s sons, swear by the gods and the king that they will observe (izuzzu) what has been established by the court verdict (dīnu) in the lawsuit that C1, C2, C3 and C4 brought against them. A document (šaṭāru) attesting that they are free of claims (ana zakî) has been given to them (nadānu N, wr. in-na-AM-din). Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Itti-Nabû-balāṭu, son of B; A2 = Bēl-kēšir, son of B; B = Šulāya//Egibi; C1 = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; C2 = Nabû-zēru-iqīša/Aplāya//Egibi; C3 = Nabû-aplu-iddin/Nabû-lē’i//Egibi; C4 = Nabu-udammiq/Bēl-ahhē-iddin

elementText.text:
House rental.
A rents a house to B for 1/3 m 5 shekels of stamped silver (ginnu) per year. The house is located next to the house that belongs to three brothers (C1, C2 and C3).  It is agreed that half of the silver should be paid at the beginning of the year, and the remainder in the middle. The renter should pay for the additional payment (nūptu) in Nisan (I), Dûzu (IV) and Kislim (IX). He should also carry out repairs to the house (batqa ṣabātu) and caulk (šanû) the roof.  A will be charged (manû) for whatever work (dullu) that is to be done in it with bricks (libnāte) and reeds (qanâte), for maximum 2 shekels of silver. Names of 5 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Iddināya/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Saggilāya; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; C1 = Bēl-…; C2 = Bēl-bullissu; C3 = Nidintu

elementText.text:
About the purchase of land: undertaking to pay the rest of the purchase price after the acknowledgment by witnesses.
A (who acts as C’s proxy, though this is not explicitly stated in the text) owes 14 1/2 shekels of silver to B. This is what remains (rīhtu) to be paid after C purchased 0;0.3 Kor (1350 m2) of agricultural land, a jointly held property to which B (pūt zittu) has title and of which C and his brothers are co-owners. The buyer is afraid that members of the seller’s family could go against this sell: thus, he asks them to be included among the witnesses of this deal. He will give the silver, 14 ½ shekels, to B as soon as (ūmu ša) the brothers of B and fD, the wife of B’s father, will be listed in C’s sealed document among the witnesses. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Šāpik-zēri/Nabû-šumu-iddin//Nādin-še'im; B = Nabû-mušētiq-uddê/Rēmūt//Eppeš-ilī; C = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; fD = fṬābatu, wife of B’s father

elementText.text:
Purchase of land.
A purchases a plot of land, whose description is largely lost in the damaged upper part of the tablet, from a person whose name is also lost. The land lower side in the South borders on the buyer’s property and (the land of) B1 and B2; its upper front in the West borders on (the land of) C1 und C2, and its lower front in the East on (the land of) fD. The total surface of the field is 0;0.1.1 Kor (525 m2); A declares the equivalent of the field (mahīra nabû) to be an amount of silver which is lost in a lacuna. The seller acknowledges that he has received (mahāru) the total amount due for the purchase of his field, and he is satisfied (apālu  G Stat); the usual warranty clauses must have followed, but the tablet is broken. The names of the witnesses and the scribe are lost.
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; B1 = Rēmūt/Nādin//Sîn-šadûnu; B2 = Bēl-iddin/Nādin//Sîn-šadûnu; C1 = Marduk-…/Nādin-ahi//Adad-šumu-ēreš; C2 = Bēlšunu/Nādin-ahi//Adad-šumu-ēreš; fD = fSi…/Šamaš-erība//Šangû-…

elementText.text:
Receipt for silver: partial repayment on a purchase of land.
A receives 1 mina and 59 shekels of medium quality silver, of which 1/8 is alloy, from B as partial repayment of a debt (u‘iltu) of 8 minas and 10 shekels of silver. This is what remains (rīhtu) to be paid of the price (whose total amount is not specified) for arable land (zēru) that he bought from the recipient. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: B.
 
A = Ea-aplu-iddin/Mušēzib-Marduk//Ṭābih-kāri; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi

elementText.text:
Undertaking to pay a half share (in a business partnership?).
In this document, A commits to show (kalāmu D) the utensils (udû) and something else (wr. LUṬ-a-ME!-tu4, meaning unknown) that are registered in a promissory note (u’iltu) to B1 and B2, C’s sons, and to hand over to them their half share (ahu). A also takes an oath (elû Š) by the divine Great Star before B1 and B2, concerning the rest (rīhu) of the utensils and his(?) share. Names of 8 witnesses and the scribe: A.
 
A = Kalbāya/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B1 = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi, son of C; B2 = Nergal-ušezib/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi, son of C; C = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi

elementText.text:
Establishment of a business partnership.
A invests 12 minas of stamped(?) silver (ginnu (silver) used for purchases and sales (nadānu u mahāru) in a business partnership with B. The partners agree that B will give (nadānu) an equal share (ahu zitti) to A in whatever he makes with the mentioned 12 minas of silver. Furthermore, the present document stipulates that B will not enter into another business partnership (harrānu alāku) besides (elat) the present one. Similarly, A does not have another business partnership (ina harrāni ianû) besides the present one. B guarantees the capital sum of the mentioned silver [i.e., 12 minas] and will run the business (našpartu ša harrāni alāku). Names of 5 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Bēl-kāṣir/Marduk-ušallim//Ašlāku

elementText.text:
Transfer of ownership, subject to life interest
fA, of her own free will (ina hūd libbišu), has transferred the ownership of her properties (nikkassu) located inside and outside the city to her daughter fB under a sealed document (kanāku - dagālu Š). The transferred amount does not include 5 minas of silver, 2 slaves (amīlūtu) and household goods (udê bīti), that she previously gave to C as her daughter’s dowry (nudunnû). As long as fA will live, she will enjoy the usufruct (akalu akālu) of her assets. She cannot transfer the property (of anything) to anyone, on her own authority (šalāṭu - nadānu). The text also records that fB will not give any of the properties inherited from her mother to anyone, without (the consent of) her husband, C. When fA will die, her assets will be at fB’s disposal (ina pāni dagālu N). The text ends invoking the gods’ curse upon whomever will change (enû) the words written in this agreement (dabābu). Names of 6 witnesses and the scribe.
 
fA = fSilim-Ištar/Kurigalzu//Ša-nāšišu; fB = fGula-qā’išat, daughter of fA; C = Bēl-ušallim/Zēria//Nabāya

elementText.text:
Receipt for silver: separate payment for yield.
fA1 and A2 receive (eṭeru) silver (the exact amount is not recorded in the text) from B, who previously purchased (mahīra epēšu) a plot of arable land (zēru) situaled along C’s sluice channel (bitqu) from them. This is the price for the yield (ebūru) of that date palm grove for Cyrus 7th year. The related text BM32204 (Wunsch 2000, 70) shows that the land which B bought was an orchard planted with date palms: since the purchase took place shortly before the date harvest, the buyer must pay separately for it. Names of 2 witnesses (including Nabû-kuzub-ilī/Šūzubu/Šigûa, brother of fA1) and the scribe.
 
fA1 = fTašmētu-damqat/Šūzubu//Šigûa; A2 = Nādin/Rēmūt//Eppeš-ilī; B = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; C = Ile’’i-Bēl

elementText.text:
Summon.
By Nisan (I), 19th, A will come and settle the accounts (nikkassu epēšu) with B, with regard to the interests on 2 minas of silver and 1 talent (c. 30000 gr.) of wool. Should A not come to do this calculations, B will take (našû, wr. it-ta-ši, Perf.) that sum of silver together with its interests, and […] as written in the previous promissory note (u’iltu). Names of 2(?) witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Amurru-zēru-ibni/Amurru-rīhtu-uṣur (family name uncertain); B = Šulāya/Nabû-zēru-ukīn//Egibi

elementText.text:
Warranty.
A takes over the duty to stand guarantee for C from B. Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Bēl-iddin/Bēl-erība; B = Širku/Iddināya//Egibi (aka: Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi); C = Ubār/Ubār (sic

elementText.text:
Promissory oath about debt repayment
B swears (tamû) by Bēl, Nabû and king Darius to A: "Until (adi) the 15th day of Ṭebēt (X) of Darius’ 11th year I will bring and hand over (našû – nadānu) the 8 kor (c. 1440 liters) of barley, the 34 kor (c. 6120 liters) of dates and the 13 shekels of silver that I owe you to your slave C." The payment is secured by the pledge (maškanu šakānu) of B’s slave D to C. Should B fail to meet the deadline, his slave D will belong (dagālu) henceforth to A, for its exact price (šīm hariṣ), in lieu of the 34 kor dates and the 13 shekels of silver, and he should deliver the indebted 8 kor of barley to A according to (akī) Babylon’s market value (mahīru). If he meets the deadline and accordingly delivers the barley, dates and silver on the 15th day, he will be allowed to take along (abāku) his slave D. B swears by Bēl, Nabû and king Darius to A: "The deadline (adannu) of the promissory note (u’iltu) will not be missed (etēqu).” At this point in the story, it is pointed out that 14 kor of dates and 16 kor of barley have already been delivered (našû, G. Stat.), and that a warranty (pūtu) for B and the 13 shekels of silver has been arranged (šakānu, G. Stat.) as well as a warranty that guarantees (našû) for the words spoken by (ana pī) A’s father (erroneously wr. Imu-du.gur, Iddin-Nergal for Nergal-iddin). Names of 10 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Ardia/Nergal-iddin; C = Madānu-iddin, slave (qallu) of A; D = Nergal-bulliṭanni, slave (qallu) of B.

elementText.text:
Addendum to a slave sale.
A sold his female slave fC to B for its full value, 1 1/3 minas of silver being the agreed-upon purchase price. The present document was drafted with the sole aim to point out that the buyer's mother (fD) was present to witness (ana šibûti ašābu) the purchase, thus implying her consent to it. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe. The sale of this female slave is recorded in BM30600.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Marduk-šumu-ibni/šumu-ukīn//Ile’’i-bulliṭ-Marduk; fC = fŠidatu; fD = fKaššāya, mother of B

elementText.text:
Settlement of a silver debt by selling a house.
B owes 5/6 minas of silver to A1 and sold his house to C (in order to raise the silver needed to pay off his debt) (ana kaspi mahāru, lit. “C bought for silver”). The debt was a claim (rašûtu) for building plots (qanû) which the original creditor had transferred (pāni šudgulu) to the (present) creditor (rašūtānu).  It had been agreed that 1/3 minas of the purchase price should be used to pay off (eṭēru N) the creditor (akī rašūtāni). In the present document, the creditor’s son  (A2) acknowledges his receipt (eṭēru) of the said sum of silver from D, who acted as proxy on behalf (ina našparti) of C, the buyer of (B’s) house. E guarantees for the payment of the 1/3 minas of silver as long as A2 has not informed (qabû) the royal scribes (ṭupšarru ša šarri) and made out a sealed tablet certifying full payment (ṭuppi apiltu). Furthermore, A2 gives C the promissory note (u’iltu) for the 2/3 minas of silver which B owed to A1 (and which C apparently paid for). Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Bēl-zēru-ibni/Šāpik-zēri//Nappāhu; A2 = Marduk-aplu-uṣur/Bēl-zēru-ibni//Nappāhu, son of Bēl-zēru-ibni/Šāpik-zēri//Nappāhu; B = Nabû-aplu-iddin/Balāṭu//Ša-nāšīšu; C = Neriglissar/Bēl-šumu-iškun; D = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; E = Nabû-ahhē-bulliṭ/Nabû-šumu-iddin//Ea-pattanu

elementText.text:
Interim account for silver, barley and dates. Description of the appropriate procedure to account for transfers and collect outstanding amounts.
Concerns 10 minas of silver, 100 kor of barley, 100 kor of dates that A has given to fB1, his wife and fB2 in a sealed document (kanāku – nadānu): of it 3 1/2 minas of cash silver (hāṭu) are at fB1's disposal, of which the tablets of [… uncl. passage]; 1 mina of silver is the price of  barley; 1 mina of silver is the price of 200 kor [broken off]; 20 shekels of silver is the price of the beer; and 25 shekels of silver are at C's disposal. This means that 6 minas 15 shekels (out of the above mentioned 10 minas), as well as the 100 kor of barley, the 100 kor of dates and the household utensils (udê bīti) have been received (eṭēru) by the two women from A. These transfers have been accounted for (keṣēpu) in (ana) the promissory notes for silver, barley and dates, for a value of 10 minas of silver. D will collect (esēru) each mina of it in order to put in a deposit (paqādu, ana paq-du), pay the remainder sum of 3 1/3 minas of silver to the two women in accordance with their promissory notes, and issue a document (u'iltu našû) as proof for himself. He is waiting (pānu dagālu N) for theremainder of the silver, barley and dates, for as much as there is, as well as for A's balance sheet (nikkassu). The partners to the contract have taken a copy of the document each.
 
A = Kabtia/Bēl-upahhir//Egibi; fB1 = fNamirtu; fB2 = fTillītu; C = Marduk-ēṭir/Nabû-ušallim; D = Šulāya/Nabû-zēru-ukīn//Egibi

elementText.text:
Purchase of land.
The tablet records the purchase of agricultural land; the text has been divided into paragraphs, marked on the tablet by a line drawn at the end of each one (and indicated below in the paraphrase by LINE).
A1 and A2 purchase 0;1 Kor (2700 m2) of agricultural land (zēru) located in the open country (eqel ṣēri) from B: it is a cultivated date garden (kirû gišimmarē zaqpi) bearing fruit (iṣṣi bilti), located in the meadowland (ugār) of the Bitqu-ša-Ile’’i-Bēl in front of the Zababa Gate in the district (pīhatu) of Babylon. LINE
Its lower side in the West, 432 cubits (216 m) long, borders on (the property of) the buyer B and the lower side in the East, with the same length, borders on (the property of) C and his brothers. The upper front in the North, 25 cubits (12,5 m) long, borders again on (the property of) B, and the lower front in the South, with the same length, is also adjacent to (the property of) B. In total, the area (mišihti) of this field is 0;1 Kor (2700 m2). LINE
A1 and A2 declare the equivalent for this land together with the seller B (A itti B mahīra nabû išām) to be 1 shekel of silver for each 0;0.0.0.6 Kor (45 m2). They pay (nadānu) the seller 1 mina of silver as total purchase price (šīmišu gamrūtu), plus 3 shekels of silver as additional payment (kî atri). The total, thus, amounts to 1 mina and 3 shekels of silver in pieces (šibirtu).
B acknowledges that he has received (mahāru) the total amount of silver corresponding to the purchase price of his field, and he is satisfied (apālu  G Stat). The parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other, not even between members of their families – otherwise, any future claimant (pāqirānu) will have to repay twelvefold the silver he received. The royal scribes will put the agreement down in writing (šaṭāru) and give the document to A1 and A2, in order to make sure that it will not be changed in the future. Fingernail impressions (ṣupru) of the seller B, instead of his seal impression (kunukku). At the end of the tablet, B promises that he will not withhold (kalû) water from A1 and A2. Names of 6 witnesses (including fD, B’s wife) and the scribe.
 
A1 = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; A2 = Rēmūtu/Kurbanni-Marduk//Ea-eppeš; B = Nergal-iddin/Nabû-kāṣir//Eppeš-ilī; C = Balāṭu/…-ušabši; fD = Nuptāya, wife of B

elementText.text:
IS THE PARAPHRASE OF DAR 395//DAR 396
Establishment of a business partnership (harranu).
A invests 100 kor of dates, 50 kor of barley (and) 60 pieces of empty barrels in a business partnership with his slave B1 and B2. The parties agree that B1 and B2 can divide (ahatašunu) whatever they make in or out of town with the said dates and barley between them, as long as they pay A yearly a fixed sum of  2 minas of silver. The document states further that the dates and barley stay at their disposal for three years. During this three-year period A cannot collect house rent from them. In the beginning of the third year, they should deliver the dates, the barley and the barrels without interest to A in Bīt-Hahhuru. Names of 6 witnesses, the scribe: Ubār//Ša-nāšīšu (= B2), and 4 additional witnesses (mentioned after the date). The 2nd additional witness’ patrinomy could not be copied by the scribe, hence he noted “broken” (hepû). His name is preserved in the BM30371 (= Dar 396).
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B1= Nabû-ayyālu, slave of A; B2 = Ubār/Ina-tēšê-ēṭir//Ša-nāšīšu

elementText.text:
Hiring of a slave.
A leases (ana idi nadānu) his slave C to B, for a monthly payment of 0;4,1 kor (c. 150 l) of barley. B should pay monthly wages (mandattu) to the slave’s owner; moreover, he must provide for C’s maintenance (kurummatu) from his own assets. The slave will be at B’s disposal from 11th of Šabāṭ (XI) onward. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Kurbanni-Marduk/Etellu//Ēṭiru.
 
A = Bēlšunu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Kubia/Nabû-rīhtu-uṣur; C = Uqūpu, slave of B; D1 = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Bēlšunu//Dannēa; D2 = Marduk-šumu-iddin/Šullumu/Itinnu; D3 = Mīna-ana-Bēl-dan/Nabû-bān-ahi//Egibi

elementText.text:
Court order?
It concerns the land in the meadowland (ugāru) of Qalūnu, in the district (pīhatu) of Kutha which A purchased from B: he is entitled (uzzuzu Š) to (that) field (eqlu) and enjoyes (akālu) its yield (ebūru). Then, he gave 20 shekels of silver to B and took as a pledge (maškanu ṣabātu) the rest (rēhtu) of the land. Then a dispute arose. Remainder broken off. This tablet is perhaps a duplicate copy of RCT22 (= Wunsch 2000, 4).
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; B= Zēria/Nergal-uballiṭ//Sagdidi

elementText.text:
Purchase of land by proxy.
A purchased 4 Kor (54000 m2) of agricultural land (zēru) from B, on the 24th Tašrīt (VII) of Nebuchadnezzar’s 3rd year (see BM32849 and its duplicate BM30338). The land consists of a cultivated date garden (kirû gišimmarē zaqpi) along the bank (kišādu) of the Banītu-Canal, in front of (mehrat) the Zababa Gate in the district (pīḫatu) of Babylon. For this land, A gave 21 minas and 20 shekels of silver (including the additional payment (atru)) to B, and he sealed the sale tablet in his own name Several months later (the tablet is dated to 14th Intercalary Addar (XII2) of the same year), he concludes the deal with C1 and C2 on whose behalf he bought the land, acting as their  proxy (ina našparti). The rest of the reverse and the beginning of the obverse are broken, only the final lines of the document are extant. These establish that should a duplicate (gabrû) of the original document related to the purchase of the land be found in A’s house or anywhere else, this belongs to C1 and C2. The two buyers also confirm that they are entitled to equal shares (ahāta) in the land. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Kabti-ilī-Marduk/Nabû-tabni-uṣur//Egibi; B = Nabû-šumu-uṣur/Nabû-kuzub-ilī//Rabi-banû; C1 = Bānūnu/Ṣillāya//Rab-banê; C2 = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi

elementText.text:
Purchase of land.
The tablet records the purchase of agricultural land; the text has been divided into paragraphs, marked on the tablet by a line drawn at the end of each one (and indicated below in the paraphrase by LINE).
A purchases 2 Kor (27000 m2) of agricultural land (zēru) in the open country (eqel ṣēri) from B. It consists partly of a cultivated date garden (kirû gišimmarē zaqpi) bearing fruit (iṣṣi bilti), and partly (adi) of wasteland (zēru kišubbû). It is located above and below the royal street  in Litamu, in front of the Ura§-Tor, in the district (pīhatu) of Babylon. LINE
Its upper side in the North borders on the land which was part of the dowry (zēru nudunnû) of fD, the buyer's wife; its lower side in the South borders on the ditch (harru) of the Ilutilati family and near (the property of) the sons of E. Its upper front in the West borders on (the property of) F and its lower front in the East on the Euphrates. No side lengths are given in the record. LINE
The land planted with trees (zēru zaqpu), 1;3.2 Kor (22500 m2), is sold for 11 shekels per (kî) 0;0.1 Kor (450 m2) of land – and the wasteland (zēru kišubbû), 0.1.4 Kor (4500 m2), is sold for 1 shekel per (kî) 0;0.1 Kor (450 m2) of land. Thus the total value (šuqultu) of the orchard is 9 minas and 10 shekels, and the total value of the wasteland is 10 shekels. A declares its equivalent together with the seller B (itti B A mahīra nabû išām) to be 9 minas and 20 shekels of silver for its total price, plus  10 shekels of silver as additional price (ki atri). LINE
B acknowledges that he has received (mahāru) 9 minas and 30 shekels of silver in pieces (šibirtu) from A, the price (šīmu) for his field, and he is satisfied (apālu  G Stat). The parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other, not even between members of their families – otherwise, any future claimant (pāqirānu) will have to repay twelvefold the silver he received. An additional clause states that A did not use any silver from C’s (i.e. his father’s) assets for the purchase. Fingernail impressions (ṣupru) of the seller B instead of his seal impression (kunukku). Names of 6 witnesses and a scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Kalbāya/Ṣillāya//Nabāya; C = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; fD = fAmat-Bāba; E = Nabû-ittannu; F = Nabû-ušallim/Abu-ul-īde

element.name: Museum No.
element.description: Museum number of cuneiform tablet

elementText.text:
Purchase of land.
The tablet records the purchase of agricultural land which, given its irregular shape, is calculated according to seven different measured areas: each one of these smaller plots is described separately, marked on the tablet by a line drawn at the end of each paragraph (and indicated below in the paraphrase by LINE).
A1 und A2 purchase 1 kor (13500 m2) agricultural land (zēru) from B: this consists of a date garden (kirû gišimmarē zaqpi) located in the open country (eqel ṣēri), cultivated with big as well as young date palms (tālu), in front of the Zababa Gate in the district (pīhatu) of Babylon. LINE
1) The first area (mišihtu) measures 0;2.0.5.2+x Kor (5790+ m2) in total. Its upper side in the West is 700 cubits (350 m) long and it borders on some property whose details are lost, the second measured area listed below (libbū eqli) , and the field of fC; its lower side in the East, which has the same length as the upper side, borders on (the property of) A1 und A2. Its upper front in the North is 35 cubits (17,5 m) long and borders on the royal street (harrān šarri) along the bank (kišādu) of the Banītu-Canal; its lower front in the South is 32 2/3 cubits (c. 16,5 m) long and it borders on the next measured area.
2) The second area (mišihtu) measures 0;0.5.5 Kor (2625 m2) in total. Its upper side in the West, 300 cubits (150 m) long, borders on a plot of 0.0.0.5.6 2/3 Kor (425 m2) with x cubits long short sides, and on the property of fC, mother of D1 and D2; its lower side in the East, which has the same length as the upper side borders on the property of A1 und A2. Its upper front in the North, 32 2/3 cubits (c. 16,3 m) long, borders on the first plot, an unknown amount of cubits of its lower front in the South borders on the next measured area (libbū eqli). LINE
3) The surface of the third measured area (mišihtu) is lost in a lacuna. Its long sides are 300 cubits (150 m) long and border on the property of fC in the West and on the land of A1 and A2 in the East. The front sides, whose lengths are also lost, are adjacent to the second plot in the North and to the next measured area (libbu eqli) in the South. LINE
4) The fourth measured area (mišihtu), of an unknown size, has the same lengths and neighbours for the long sides: 300 cubits (150 m), fC in the West, and A1 and A2 in the East. Its upper front side in the North is 20 2/3 cubits (c. 10,3 m) long and borders on the previous (third) measured area, while its lower front in the South, 16 1/2 cubits (c. 8,25 m) long, borders on the measured area (libbū eqli). LINE
5) The surface area of the fifth plot (mišihtu) is also lost in a lacuna. Its long sides are 300 cubits (150 m) long and border on the property of fC in the West and on the land of A1 and A2 in the East. The upper front in the North, 16 1/2 cubits (c. 8,25 m) long, is adjacent to the previous (fourth) plot in the North; its lower front side in the South is 10 cubits (5 m) long and borders on the next plot (libbū eqli). LINE
6) The sixth measured area (mišihtu), whose size is lost in a lacuna, has once again the same lengths and neighbours for its long sides: 300 cubits (150 m), fC in the West, and A1 and A2 in the East. Its upper front side in the North is 10 cubits (5 m) long and is adjacent to the previous (fifth) measured area, while the lower front side in the South borders on the next plot. LINE
7) The last measured area (mišihtu), of unknown size, has shorter sides. The long ones measure 250 cubits (125 m) and border once again on fC in the West, and A1 and A2 in the East – while its upper front in the North is adjacent to the previous (sixth) plot. LINE
A1 and A2 declare the equivalent for this land together with the seller B (A itti B mahīra nabû išām) to be 1 shekel each X kor of land (the exact amount is lost in a lacuna of the tablet). From a broken passage it is possible to infer that the buyers have given (nadānu) some minas and shekels of silver corresponding to the entire purchase price (šīmišu gamrūtu) of this field, plus more silver as additional payment (kî atri). LINE
The seller acknowledge that he has received the full amount of silver in pieces (šibirtu), and he is satisfied (apālu  G Stat). The following lines, in fragmentary condition, must have recorded the warranty clause against future claims between the parties or members of their families. Names of 5 witnesses and 2 scribes. The exact measurements of each plot of land are recorded in BM30933.
 
A1 = Nergal-Bānûnu/Ṣillāya//Rab-banê; A2 = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; B = Nabû-šumu-uṣur/Nabû-kuzub-ilī//Rab-banê; fC = fŠahundu /…, mother of D1 and D2; D1 = Nabû-etel-ilī; D2 = Nabû-uṣur-napišti

elementText.text:
Receipt
A receives (mahāru) 6 shekels of silver from B for C’s urāšu-obligation. This is in addition (elat) to the receipt (giṭṭu) of a previous 9 shekels of silver that D received (mahāru) from B. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe. 
 
A = Nergal-ahhē-iddin/Erība-Marduk//Šigūa; B = Marduk-rēmanni/Iddin-Marduk/Nūr-Sîn; C = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; D = Lâbāši

elementText.text:
Fixation of interest on a silver debt. Apparently related to money lending within the context of a business partnership.
B owes a broken amount of silver to A, slave of C. It is the capital sum (qaqqadu) and its interest (hubullu) of a debt on which he should (continue) pay(ing) a yearly interest of 20% on a monthly basis. The loan includes (adi) silver from his share (pūt zitti) (in a partnership) with (itti) the brothers D1 and D2. Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nergal-rēṣūa, slave of C; B = Lâbāši/Nabû-bān-ahi//Kidin-Sîn; C = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; D1 = Nabû-eṭēr-napšāti/Ea-lūmur; D2 = Kalbāya/Ea-lūmur

elementText.text:
Memorandum about a delivery of onions. Partial receipt.
It concerns the 150000 strings (gidlu) of onions that had been delivered to D and about which C wrote a message (šipirtu) to B1 and B2  (apparently, urging them to deliver the onions  to him). The present tablet is written in order not to forget (tahsistu la mašê) that A1, C’s slave, and A2 received 124000 strings (gidlu) of (the said 150000) onion strings on behalf of (ina našparti) C, from B1 and B2. and that 18000 of them belong to E. Written in the presence (ina ušuzzu) of 2 witnesses. No scribe.
 
A1 = Arad-Bēl, slave of C; A2 = Nabû-aplu-iddin/Šilāya/Esagilia; B1 = Nabû-ēṭir; B2 = Nādinu; C = Iddin-Marduk(/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn); D = Zababa-ahu-iddin; E = Šūzubu

elementText.text:
Undertaking to pay
B owes something to A1 and his slave A2. The first part of the first line is broken, so what B owes is not known. B will go (alāku) to Babylon on the 20th day of Kislīm (IX) and will pay (eṭēru) according to (akī) A1’s promissory notes (u'iltu). This is in addition (elat) to A2’s … (broken off) that is at B’s disposal (ina pāni). Apart from the first witness, the names of the other 2 witnesses and the scribe are fragmentary.
 
A1 = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; A2 = Madān-bēlu-uṣur; B = Gūzānu/Nabû-nāṣir/Sîn-nāṣir

elementText.text:
Takeover of a payment obligation.
The tablet is related to promissory notes (u’iltu) held by A1 and A2, to the debit of B1 and B2. B2 guarantees for B1, for the payment (eṭēru) of the silver. He will bring A1‘s and A2‘s promissory notes and hand them over (našû - nadānu) to B1. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-ēṭir-napšāti/Kiribtu//Bēl-aplu-uṣur.
 
A1 = Šumu-iddin; A2 = Šamaš-šumu-ukīn; B1 = Iddin-Marduk;  B2 = Nabû-ušallim

elementText.text:
Settlement of accounts.
On the day when A comes and draws up the accounts (nikkassu epēšu) with B, B will pay (nadānu) the amount of silver which has been charged (elû) to him, capital and interest (kaspu u hubullu). The silver, as much as (is needed for) the settlement of accounts, is charged (elû) to A. C will pay (nadānu) the capital and interest (kaspu u hubullu) for this debt. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe: Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi
 
A = Nabû...šari; B = Arad-Bēl; C = Nabû-bēlšunu

elementText.text:
Sale of a slave.
A, of his own free will, sells his female slave (qallatu) fC to B for  the full purchase price of 1 mina of silver. A guarantees against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that C is a free person (mār banê). Names of 5 witnesses and the scribe: Erībāya/Balāssu//Eppeš-ilī
 
A = Šumāya/Erēbšu; B = Silīm-Bēl/Marduk//Damqa; fC = fHabaṣītu

elementText.text:
Promissory note. Fragmentary
B owes A 5 minas of silver. He will pay this amount and its interest(?) to A in Ayyār (II). He already paid what remained (to be paid) (rīhtu) of the 10 minas of silver that his father owed to A.  Apart from the fragmentary first two names of the witnesses, the list of witnesses and the name of the scribe are broken.
 
A = Nabû-mukīn-zēri/…; B = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi

elementText.text:
About a fugative female slave. Partly unclear.
The case at hand is that of C, a female slave belonging to A who cannot be found. Should she be seen (amāru N, wr. ta-at-ta-na-ma-ru) with (ina pāni) B, where (ašar) …, (then?) they know (idú) that … should(?) he not heed to it(?) (našu, wr. it-ta-aš-šú) and he (šū) even helps her on her way out(?) (harrānu ana šēpē šakānu)(*), B …. belongs to A (ša A šū).
Notes: (*). CAD: to satisfy someone.
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; B = Kalbāya/Marduk-erība; C = f…-tu, female slave of A

elementText.text:
Securities for a silver debt: pledge of a house and interest
B1 and his wife (fB2) owe ½ minas and 6 shekels of silver to A, which is secured by a lien on the debtors' entire house until the creditor is paid back in full his silver. Additional securities are in place: on part of this debt, namely 26 shekels, the debtors will have to pay a yearly interest of 20%, to be paid on a monthly basis. The remaining 10 shekels is interest-free as it is secured by the pledge in antichresis of the east part of the debtors' house ("no rent on the house, and no interest on the silver").  Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe: B1. Written in the presence (ina ašābi) of the debtor's mother (fC).
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B1 = Nādin/Nergal-ēṭir/Bābūtu; fB2 = fNuptaia/Nabû-mušētiq-uddê//Esagilāya, wife of B1; fC= fBēlessunu, mother of B1

elementText.text:
Summons to end a case
In this fragmentary document, A swears that by an unknown day of Intercalary Ulūl (VI2) he will come (alāku) and bring to an end (qatû D) his case (dibbu) with fB about silver and barley. Should he not come, he will pay the 6 shekels of silver (that he owes) to fB, without (ša lā) [… uncl.). He will return (târu) everything that he has […] from the hands of fB [...]. fC guarantees for the (re)payment (eṭēru) of the silver and barley. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe: Marduk-ušallim/Erîba-Marduk//Mandidi.
 
A = Kalbāya/Nergal-ušēzib; fB = fLū-balṭat; fC = fGagāya

elementText.text:
Memorandum concerning the expenditure of barley.
The document lists the distribution of barley to three recipients (fA1, A2, A3).
fA1, slave of B receives 4 kor. A2, slave of C receives 2 kor. A3 of the Bēlillatāya house: 0;2.3.0 kor. In total 6;2.3.0 kor of barley has been removed (rêqu D) from the house. The memorandum (tahsistu) doesn’t mention any witnesses or a scribe. C can be identified as the adoptive brother of Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi. At the time of the recording of this tablet C and Iddin-Marduk are business partners. Wunsch 2000, 46 states that the distribution took place through Madānu-bēla-uṣur, slave of Iddin-Marduk.
 
fA1 = fNanāya-silim; A2 = Nabû-lū-salim A3 = Bēlšunu//Bēl-illatāya; B = Nergal-ahu-iddin; C = Kalbāya

elementText.text:
Fulfilment of a dowry promise. Receipt of silver instead of a share in a building plot.
Concerns fA2 dowry. Her father (B) still owes her and her husband (A1) [x] minas of silver, the equivalent (šimu) for (a share in) the building plot (qanû), which he apparently promised to give as part of her dowry. In addition (elat), he also owes her 5 minas out of the 18 minas of (promised) dowry silver, as well as the 10 slaves (amēluttu)  and household utensils that are still with him.  In addition (elat) to a dowry, B handed out a sealed document in which he transferred (kanāku – nadānu) one third (šalšu) of his property (nikkassu) to A1 via (itti) fA2. The house in which B resides (ašābu), C, his son, will inherit (NÍ TA BI, Wunsch 1993, 114) (or: he [B] has contractually assigned to C, ir!-ta-kás [rakāsu], Roth, JAOS 111 (1991), 21 n. 4).
A1 and fA2 acknowledge their receipt (mahāru) of the silver for fA2's share (pūt zittišu) in the building plot on which B resides. Names of 3 witnesses, including Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulaya//Egibi, the father of A1 and the scribe: Šāpik-zēri/Nabû-šumu-iddin//Nādin-še'im.
 
A1=Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi fA2= fNuptāya/Iddin-Marduk//Nūr-Sîn, wife of A1 and daughter of B; B= Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn, father of fA2; C=Marduk-rēmanni/Iddin-Marduk

A = Šamaš-šumu-ukīn/Nabû-kāṣir/Sagdidi; B = Madān-šumu-iddin/Zeria/Nabāya; C = Nabû-bēl- ilāni/Murānu

elementText.text:
Interim settlement of accounts, within the framework of a business partnership.
Three business partners divide the profits of their partnership in three equal shares as agreed (aki zittišunu). A receives (mahāru)  1 mina of silver, his one-third share in the profits of the business partnership that he owns together with B and C. The silver is what had been paid to the partners in installments (ša ina mînišu mahāru) while trading their onions (ana šūmi). B  receives (mahāru) the 1 mina of silver that had been recorded in his tablet (ina ṭuppi šakānu). C can take (našû) the 1 mina of silver that is about to arrive (erēbu). 
 
A = Iddin-Marduk/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn; B = Ea-nāṣir(/Mušallim//Šangû-Nanāya); C = Marduk-ēṭir

elementText.text:
House Rental.
A rents his house to B for 5 years. It is agreed that half of the silver should be paid at the beginning of the year, and the remainder in the middle. The renter should caulk (šanû) the roof and repair the wall foundations (asurrû). Should one of the parties break (nabalkutu) the contract, he will have to pay 10 shekels of silver. The renter will give the silver to fC, A’s wife. Name of 1 witness and the scribe.
 
A = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; B = Nabû-mukīn-apli/Ina-Esagila-zēra-ibni//Ir’anni; fC = fNuptaia

elementText.text:
Receipt for silver. Purchase price for land paid to sellers’ creditor.
A purchases a plot of land (eqlu) from fB1, fB2 und fB3 but pays the purchase price (or part of it), 2 minas, to a third party (C) who had a claim against the sellers that was recorded in a document (u’iltu e’elû) before judges (dayyānu). C acknowledges his receipt (eṭēru) of the silver. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; fB1 = fNadāya/Šamaš-udammiq//Maštuk; fB2 = fIna-Esagil-rāmat/Šamaš-udammiq//Maštuk; fB3 = fBēlilitu/Šamaš-udammiq//Maštuk; C = Nabû-mukīn-apli/Nabû-zēru-līšir//Itinnu

elementText.text:
Purchase of land.
A purchases land from B: given its irregular surface area, it was divided into three portions (mišihtu). All the neighbouring properties on each side are recorded in the first lines of the text, however this information is lost because of the damaged condition of the tablet. Only the property adjacent to third portion's lower front in the East is known: it is adjacent to (the property) of C. A declares the equivalent for this land together with the seller B, 3 Kor (40500 m2) in total, to be 14 shekels of silver per 0;0.1 Kor (450 m2) (A itti B mahīra nabû išām). He pays the total purchase price of 21 minas, plus 40 shekels as additional payment (kî pî atri). B acknowledges that he has received (mahāru) in total 21 minas and 40 shekels of silver in pieces (šibirtu), and he is satisfied. The parties agree that in future times there will be no claims or suits against each other, not even between members of their families – otherwise, any future claimant (pāqirānu) will have to repay twelvefold the silver he received. One final sentence, written after the date and only partially readable, mentions a purchase price (mahīru) and again a date – but it is not possible to say to which deal this formula is referring to. 9 witnesses (names lost) and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Šumu-iddin/Šāpik-zēri//Nabāya; C = Nabû-zēru-iqīša

elementText.text:
About the purchase of land: undertaking to pay the purchase price to the seller’s creditors.
A undertakes to pay 55 shekels of silver to fB1 and her son B2: this sum corresponds to the price of a field purchased from fC1, fC2 and fC3, and the silver is his at his disposal (ina pānīšu). fB1 and B2 are the seller’s creditors (rāšû): A will pay them off on the 25th of Ulūl (VI), as established in a trial whose verdict has been written down in a document that fB1 and B2 handed over to A. Names of 5 witnesses (the judges, dayyāne) and the scribe. The trial mentioned in this text is recorded in BM31961.
 
A = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; fB1 = fHibbuṣu/Marduk-šarrani; B2 = Mušēzib-Marduk, son of fB1; fC1 = fNadāya; fC2 = fIna-Esagila-rāmat; fC3 = fBēlilitu

elementText.text:
Share-farming agreement for a cow
The text is related to a brown cow, marked with the signs UD-tu-ú on its front-right thigh and on its back-thigh (ṭurru): A gives it to B in return for a share (ana zitti) in the profits from its labour, estimated at 50 shekels of white silver, of which 1/8 is alloy. The two parties agree that they are both responsible for the milk products (iškurratu) and the fodder supply (tablittu). B guarantees for the cow’s pasturing, caretaking, and  guarding (lit. ‘not escaping’), day and night. A acknowledges that he received from B the silver, a front-end payment for his half share. The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. Names of witness and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi; B = Nabû-zēru-ibni/Itti-Nabû-balāṭu/Egibi

elementText.text:
Promissory note for dates. Fragmentary.
B1 and B2 owe 3.2 kor of dates to A1 and A2. The two debtors assume warranty for each other and swore by god and king that they will deliver the dates until the end of Šabāṭ (XI). The rest of the document is broken off. Names of xxx witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; A2 = Nergal-ušallim/Šumu-iddin//Ile’’i -Marduk; B1 = Mušēzib-Marduk//Šamaš-ahu-iddin; B2 = Nergal-ušallim/Tabnēa

elementText.text:
Establishment of a business partnership.
A invests 6 minas of silver in a business partnership (harrānu) with B.
The partners agree that A is entitled (akālu) to a share in the profits (utru) that equals B's (ahu zitti).  B will do business in and out of town (ālu u ṣēru).
This silver is what remains (rīhtu) to be paid by B from the originally 11 minas of silver which A invested in the business six years earlier, in Nebuchadnezzar’s 24th year. Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe: Ēṭiru/Nabû-upahhir//Ile''i-bulluṭa-Marduk.
 
A = Mušēzib-Marduk/Lâbāši-Marduk//Ile''i-bulluṭa-Marduk; B = Kāṣir/Iqīšāya//Nūr-Sîn

elementText.text:
Settlement of business accounts.
A and B settle their accounts (epuš nikkassi qatû) with each other. They have made (epēšu, wr. ītepšū, Perf.) the necessary deductions (šumqutu) in mutual agreement (itti ahameš) for the donkeys that A gave to B, and the silver that B gave to A. The parties to the contract have taken one copy of the document each. Names of 4 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Nabû-balāssu-iqbi/Iqīša//Ahi’ūtu; B = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi

elementText.text:
Settlement of accounts.
The tablet records the settlement of the accounts (epuš nikkassi) of a business in first-draft beer (šikaru reštû) for the 13th year of Nabonidus. It is chiefly concerned with the silver sums and beer vats that have been  available to A. He had two major sums of silver at his disposal (ina pani). First, 2 minas and 52 ½ shekels of silver of which at the time of recording the present document remain 16 ½ shekels, the rest having been spent as specified in the present document. The second sum amounts to 2 minas and 55 ½ shekels of silver: its various components are specified in the present document.
The first lines list amounts of beer vats and silver, including 24(?) vats of full-strength beer (šikaru ṭābu), out of which 11 vats x x (uncl.)  what remains  (rēhtu) of the x x x (uncl.) vat(s) for 2 minas and 52 ½  shekels of silver.x x x (uncl.) the ½  mina that had been paid (manû). The said amount (of 2 minas and 52 ½ shekels) at A’s disposal (ina pāni) does not include (elat) the 2 minas and 15 shekels of silver (over which he disposes) since Ulūl (VI) of Nabonidus’ 13th regnal year.
From those 2 minas and 52 ½ shekels B1 (received) 56 shekels and B2 (received) 6 ½ shekels, so that together they owe 1 mina and 2 ½ shekels of silver to C, (plus) 1 1/3 mina and 4 ½ shekels ... (remnants of signs, uncl.) (and) apart from (elat) 7 shekels of silver which are due to D1 and 6 shekels due to(?) D2. In total, (A spent) 2 ½ minas and 6 shekels of silver (of the 2 minas and 52 ½ shekels that were at his disposal); what remains (rēhtu) therefore at A’s disposal (ina pāni A) are 16 ½ shekels of silver.
Then, the text lists 2 minas and 15 shekels of paid (manû) silver, (that have been at A’s disposal) since Ulūl (VI) of Nabonidus’ 13th regnal year, 16 ½ minas of previous (mahrû) ṭuhhû-silver, 1/3 mina and 4 shekels of previous (mahrû) ṭuhhû-silver due to A and his wife fE, and 50 vats (dannu) of good quality beer. In total, 2 minas and 55 ½ shekels of silver and 50 vats of good quality beer are at A’s disposal (ina pāni). This total does not include (elat) empty jars (dannu rīqū) and household goods (udê bīti). The document was drafted in the presence of (ina ušuzzi) F1 and F2.
 
A = Nabû-uterri; B1 = Nādinu/Ina-ṣilli-Bēl; B2 = Padāya/Hanunu; C = Nādinu/Padāya; D1 = Nabû-šumu-uṣur (without affiliation); D2 = Labaši/Bēl-reṣua; fE = fMiṣātu, wife of A; F1 = Marduk-balāssu-iqbi/Nabû-zēru-iddin//Dābibi; F2 = Nabû-uballiṭ/Nabû-aplu-iddin//Ṣāhit-ginê

elementText.text:
Summon
By Kislīm (IX), 1st,  A will present his witness in Opis. He will witness against B, (maintaining) that C, who acted as guarantor through B, at the established date [...] took the contract away (and) gave it to B. If he will be able to bring his testimony, he will go unpunished. Should he fail to present his witness, he must pay to B what is written in the promissory note, both the barley and its interests. Names of 2 witnesses. Scribe: Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi.
 
A = Gudāya/Hinni-ilī//Mar-banê; B = Bāba-ēreš/Nabû-mukīn-apli; C = Katimu’/Hagūru

elementText.text:
Sale of a slave.
A1 and his wife fA2 sell of their own free will their female slave fC to B. The agreed purchase price is 1/2 mina and 1 shekel of silver. They guarantee against (suits brought by) a person acting unlawfully (sēhû) or a person claiming (pāqirānu) that fC is a free person (mār banê). Names of 3 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A1 = Arad-Nabû/Rēmūt//Nagāru; fA2 = fBābunu/Nabû-ile''i, wife of A1; B = Nabû-ahhē-iddin/Šulāya//Egibi; fC = fKalbati

elementText.text:
Addendum to a slave sale.
A sold a female slave to B for 1 1/3 mina of silver (cf. BM30911): the buyer already paid 1 mina of silver to A and his mother (fD) at the occasion of his purchase of their plot of land located on the Zabūnu ditch. Apparently, this land sale did eventually not materialize, as goes forth from a fragmentarily preserved passage, so that the 1 mina that was paid will be credited to B for his purchase of the slave (see also BM30911). (As for) the rest (of the silver): (as soon as) fD‘s name will be included in fC’s sale document (ina ṭuppi), B will announce the (slave's?) market value (māhiru […] šemû Š) (partly uncl.) and will pay the remaining 1/3 mina to A. Names of 2 witnesses and the scribe.
 
A = Marduk-šumu-ibni/šumu-ukīn//Ile’’i-bulliṭ-Marduk; B = Itti-Marduk-balāṭu/Nabû-ahhē-iddin//Egibi; fC = fŠidatu; fD = fKaššāya, mother of A

elementText.text:
Loan ina pāni
B owes 10;3.2 kor barley (c. 1890 liters) to A. The latter is introduced by his first name, Širku, without genealogy, and is probably to be identified with Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-marduk-balāṭu, aka Širku, head of the Egibi family. The document does not relate to when or where B should return the barley which is at his disposal (ina pāni). Names of 4 witnesses, who are introduced by the fomula ina ušuzzi ša "in the presence of", followed by the name of the scribe (Bēl-iddin/Ardia//Bēl-aplu-uṣur) and two more names (additional witnesses?).
 
A = Marduk-nāṣir-apli/Itti-Marduk-balāṭu//Egibi (Š​irku, without genealogy); B = Nabû-bullissu/Nabû-šumu-uṣur//Bēl-aplu-uṣur
